description: Dive into "Whispers of Romance in Oxford" — a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Whispers of Romance in Oxford

places.generalDescription: The Ashmolean Museum, located in Oxford, is a renowned institution of art and archaeology with a rich history dating back to 1683. It houses an exceptionally diverse collection of artifacts representing various world civilizations from 8000 BC to contemporary times.

sources.snippet: If you’re trying to impress a musical other half, take them on a pilgrimage to see one of the first violins constructed by Stradivari at the Ashmolean Museum. Made by the renowned Italian musical instrument craftsman in the seventeenth century, this violin is also known as ‘The Messiah’, and is one of the famous violins in the world. So, even if you don’t feel you’re capable of playing your own string serenade, you can look at this violin and use the power of imagination to recreate the tunes of courtly love that this little instrument has sung.
sources.shortName: The Most Romantic Places in Oxford

sources.snippet: A visit to the Ashmolean Museum is an excellent choice for a culturally enriching first date. As the world’s first university museum, it houses a diverse collection that spans centuries and continents, offering something of interest to everyone. Walking through the exhibits, you’ll find yourselves discussing everything from ancient civilizations to modern art, providing a wealth of topics for engaging conversation.
sources.shortName: First Date Ideas in Oxford

sources.snippet: Travel back to a bygone era of artistic romance by admiring masterpieces by Goya, Van Gogh and JMW Turner at the Ashmolean Museum. See displays of jewellery, musical instruments, textiles and other old-world antiquities at the Pitt Rivers Museum. Purchase Special Gifts and Souvenirs Treat your partner to something new from dozens of shops that spread through the heart of Oxford city centre.
sources.shortName: Romantic Things to Do in Oxford

sources.snippet: The Ashmolean Museum is a romantic building in itself, however the aura and energy from the vibrancy of stunning oil paintings and archaeological collections are something else. Silently gaze upon figures once held by historically renowned artists as muses and inspirations for their work. You, and the one who inspires you the most are sure to have a romantic and insightful experience here.
sources.shortName: Romantic Autumn Activities in Oxfordshire for Couples

sources.snippet: If you’re looking for a chilled out day date, Ashmolean Museum has that covered. Explore the famous Oxfo r d museum and all its wonderful exhibits – it also has a world famous collection of Egyptian mummies. The fun doesn’t stop there at Ashmolean, head up to its rooftop restaurant for a romantic afternoon tea paired with a picturesque view of Oxford’s spires.
sources.shortName: 11 Wonderful Date Ideas In Oxford

sources.snippet: For couples who love art and history, the Ashmolean Museum is a must-visit in Oxford. Renowned for its impressive collection of ancient artefacts and beautiful paintings, the museum offers an immersive experience that is sure to enrich your time together. You can stroll hand in hand through halls rich with history and discuss your favourite pieces.
sources.shortName: 5 Romantic Things To Do in Oxford for Couples

sources.snippet: Travelling the world has never been easier, thanks to Oxford’s museums, from the Ashmolean Museum, to the Museum of Oxford. Take your pick, or head inside the eclectic (and free) Pitt Rivers Museum, which houses half a million artefacts. Take a peek at shrunken heads, ceremonial masks and a even totem pole and pick up a memento in the gift shop.
sources.shortName: Things to Do & Places to Visit in Oxford

sources.snippet: Impress your date with your astute knowledge of Japanese military history or understanding of symbolist painting. And if you have nothing in common, this is the place to go, because gallery-goers generally remain silent. Laurie says: “Japanese military history pushes all my buttons.
sources.shortName: Best Places To Go On a Date In Oxford

sources.snippet: The Ashmolean Museum was founded in 1953 and it is Oxford University’s Museum of art and archaeology. Discover the world-famous collections ranging from Egyptian mummies to contemporary and modern art, and listen to the stories of humans across culture and across time.
sources.shortName: 20 Places to Visit in Oxford, Tourist Places & Top Attractions

sources.snippet: The Ashmolean Museum stays open late on Fridays, offering a perfect blend of culture and intimacy as you explore world treasures together.
sources.shortName: A Romantic Guide to Oxford
8 Romantic Things To Do This Valentine’s Day In Oxford

places.name: Ashmolean Museum

reviews.text: For £ 8,10 entry as a student, I visited the Ashmolean museum the Saturday before Easter Sunday. It closes a bit earlier (5pm) on that specific day but otherwise the experience was brilliant. I enjoyed the variety of art and different cultures displayed in the museum. There are good floor plans on every floor and each exhibit is numbered quite clearly. The only thing that I would have appreciated would have been a free map to carry around. There are some available in exchange for a 2£ donation though. I especially liked the Japanese exhibition and room 62. There are benches or seats in most exhibitions which allow for rests or people to sit and sketch. The museum staff were very friendly and open to questions. I especially liked the young man in room 62 and the member of staff with two nice bows in her hair. Thank you for the wonderful afternoon. I Would definitely recommend visiting this museum.

Fabulous museum packed full of interesting artifacts from all over the world. Galleries also worth a visit. Staff friendly and helpful, temperature cool, entry fee (but well worth giving a generous donation).

Lovely lunch on the terrace with attentive service also.

We toured Oxford campus and stopped into the Ashmolean for a short visit. Even with limited time, we saw some highlights and were really impressed-such a beautiful, well-curated museum. Definitely worth coming back for a longer visit!

places.address: Beaumont St, Oxford, OX1 2PH, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: Escape Hunt Oxford offers a thrilling escape room experience suitable for families and couples. The Alice in Puzzleland theme is perfect for kids as young as 8, providing an exciting 60-minute challenge that encourages teamwork and problem-solving. For a romantic date, the Westgate shopping center location features various themed rooms like Pirates and Doctor Who. Even if you don't manage to escape, you can enjoy the fully stocked bar.

sources.snippet: If it’s an exhilarating date you’re after, then head to Escape Hunt for an escape room experience in Westgate shopping centre. There are multiple different rooms to choose from with themes such as Pirates, Alice in Wonderland and Doctor Who. There is a fully stocked bar to enjoy even if you don’t manage to escape!
sources.shortName: 10 date ideas in Oxford

sources.snippet: Escape Hunt offers 6 different immersive themed rooms, from Doctor Who to Alice in Wonderland, which one will you choose?. Remember though, the clock is ticking.
sources.shortName: 8 Romantic Things To Do This Valentine’s Day In Oxford
Date Ideas Oxford: 15 Romantic Things to Do in Oxford [2024]

places.name: Escape Hunt Oxford

reviews.text: Chloë made the experience all the more special. She took great care of us, especially with my partner having epilepsy. Upon request she was more than happy to warn us for any loud noises and afterwards we still had a great chat. Very accommodating, would definitely recommend.

Amazing experience, we did the a darlek awakening room and it was so much fun and really interactive. Would 100% recommend to family's, couples and friends alike.
Ibrahim was a great host and introduced the room really well and was super friendly. He took some great photos of us at the end

The staff were extremely welcoming and enthusiastic. The puzzle itself was very fun with a good level of challenge even though we picked an easy one. Charlie was especially helpful and made our experience 2.3x better!

places.address: Roof Terrace, Westgate Centre, Castle St, Oxford OX1 1TR, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: The Covered Market, established in the 1770s, is a bustling indoor bazaar featuring artisan grocers, trendy boutiques, and lively cafes. Visitors can indulge in gourmet pies at Pieminister, savor freshly baked cookies from Ben's Cookies kiosk, and relish delectable sandwiches at Fasta Pasta. Additionally, the market offers a serene escape at the spa within the historic Macdonald Randolph Hotel.

sources.snippet: Unique and one-of-a-kind items are aplenty at the artisan stands and boutiques of the Covered Market. If your taste is more mainstream then Westgate Shopping Centre is the place for high street brands. You can also indulge in a spot of luxury retail therapy at Bicester Village.
sources.shortName: Romantic Things to Do in Oxford

sources.snippet: The Covered Market transforms into a treasure trove for couples early in the morning. Start with fresh coffee at Colombia Coffee Roasters (open Monday-Saturday 8am-5:30pm, Sunday 10am-4pm) while the market comes to life around you.
sources.shortName: A Romantic Guide to Oxford

places.name: The Covered Market

reviews.text: The market is situated in the center of Oxford. It's very nice to visit where you can buy different food, sweets or drinks, but you also find clothes, jewerly and clothing accesories. The market is among the oldest markets in the country. Well worth visiting if you explore the city. Great place for lunch or just pop in find a tasty take away and coffee or tea and get back to explore the streets of Oxford.

We stopped by the Covered Market out of curiosity, and while it's a charming and historic space, the actual shop selection did not quite live up to the hype. It was fun to walk through and take in the atmosphere-definitely quaint-but most of the stores just did not feel all that appealing to us.

Worth a quick stroll if you're nearby, but not a must-see unless you're specifically hunting for something niche.

A really charming market area, easily accessible when walking through Oxford.  We found excellent food at lunch, and came back near dinner to grab something quick to take away while closing.  I was surprised it closed so early in the summer when so many tourists and summer students around.  Great selection of eateries and cute shops.   Pieminster was a stand out for us.  Could not find any toilets here - which seemed surprising with so many eateries.  Also limited seating available.  The Alice in Wonderland references are a fun addition.

places.address: Market St, Oxford, OX1 3DZ, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: The University Church of St Mary the Virgin is a stunning CofE place of worship with an intricate 14th-century spire. It's located on the High Street and offers breathtaking views of the city from its tower, making it a perfect starting point for your day in Oxford. The church also hosts regular musical recitals and events, adding to its cultural significance.

sources.snippet: Climb the University Church of St. Mary the Virgin It’s a long, twisting climb to the tower of the University Church of St. Mary the Virgin but the views are worth every one of the 127 steps. When gazing over the city’s rooftops and university colleges you’ll soon realise where the dreaming spires nickname came from. Can you name more iconic city landmarks than your partner?.
sources.shortName: Romantic Things to Do in Oxford

sources.snippet: Put your comfiest shoes on if you're planning on climbing to the top of University Church!. It might be a bit of a climb up a winding, ancient staircase but the 360-degree panoramic view over the city from the top of the church makes it all worthwhile - spot the Radcliffe Camera and prepare to take some really stunning photos.
sources.shortName: 7 Things to do in Oxford on Your Romantic Weekend Break ...

sources.snippet: St Mary the Virgin University Church is a vibrant church located on the north side of the High Street in Oxford, United Kingdom and it is the largest of the city’s parish churches. It has been recognized as a place of Christian worship for over seven hundred years with its dignified liturgy and elegant music.
sources.shortName: 20 Places to Visit in Oxford, Tourist Places & Top Attractions

sources.snippet: Two of the most picture-postcard views of the spires are from the top of Magdalen Tower or the spire of the University Church of St Mary the Virgin on the High Street. From such a height, Oxford looks like a toy town, and you can trace the streets of the whole city spread before you.
sources.shortName: The Most Romantic Places in Oxford

places.name: University Church of St Mary the Virgin

reviews.text:
A gentleman named John showed me around - even pointing out where C. S. Lewis stood to preach, as well as the street light and the image of the hoofed Narnia character that can be found to the left side of the church when you're looking at the church from the street.

What a glorious experience. Praise be to God and a special thanks to John at University Church of St. Mary the Virgin.

A stunning and historic gem in the heart of Oxford. The church itself is beautiful, peaceful, and typically uncrowded-a perfect place to pause and reflect. Entry is free, and it's a must-see for history buffs, especially knowing that C.S. Lewis delivered his famous Weight of Glory sermon here.

Climbing the tower costs £6 and is well worth it, though be prepared: 158 steps await, with about half in a very tight spiral. It gets especially tricky at the top if it's crowded-the narrow passageways make it difficult to pass others, and the path around the tower leads to a dead end, so backtracking is required. Still, the panoramic views of Oxford, particularly of All Souls College and the Radcliffe Camera, are absolutely breathtaking.

Bonus tip: do not miss the Vaults & Garden Café right on-site. Delicious food in a beautiful setting. This church and tower climb are a highlight of any visit to Oxford.

Exquisite visit of the church, and its clock tower, with a one person colimaçon stairs, that gives access to a superb view of Oxford's 4 cardinal points. The price at 6£ is fair, the staff is friendly, and it smells like a Harry Potter's book.

places.address: The, High St, Oxford, OX1 4BJ, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: Port Meadow is an unspoiled ancient meadow located by the River Thames, offering opportunities for walks, bird watching, and observing wild ponies and wildflowers. This 440-acre grazing land runs parallel to the river's western side and provides a beautiful setting for leisurely strolls. Visitors can also enjoy a drink at historic taverns like The Perch or the Trout Inn with its riverside terrace.

sources.snippet: You’ll probably become more familiar with Port Meadow, the stretch of land beside the Thames a little north-west of the city centre, as a place to picnic and swim in the summer. However, the sense of escaping from normal uni life into the countryside, the winding paths along the riverbanks, and the occasional company of horses makes for a blissful date, and you can be rewarded at the end of your stroll at pubs such as The Perch and The Medley.
sources.shortName: Date Spots

sources.snippet: Next, Port Meadow presents a completely different but equally mesmerizing option for a romantic walk. This vast expanse of open land by the River Thames has remained untouched for centuries, offering a glimpse into England’s pastoral past. A sunset walk here can feel like stepping into another world, where the only sounds are the rustling of the grass and the distant calls of wild birds.
sources.shortName: First Date Ideas in Oxford

sources.snippet: Picnic in Port Meadow Sprawling Port Meadow skirts the River Thames and feels more like a Cotswolds countryside setting than the edge of the city centre. Fill your picnic hamper with goodies, throw down a blanket and bask amid birdsong, wildflowers and wild ponies. Why not add a bottle of champagne for a little bit of deserved indulgence?.
sources.shortName: Romantic Things to Do in Oxford

sources.snippet: Take Port Meadow at sunset – this ancient grazing land beside the Thames comes alive with wild horses roaming freely under spectacular skies. Connected to the Thames Path, it’s perfect for evening walks.
sources.shortName: A Romantic Guide to Oxford

places.name: Port Meadow

reviews.text: Beautiful day at port meadow. Lovely location for a long walk. So perfect when there's some wildlife included. Saw some wild rabbits but they ran off so quick couldn't take any pics. It was such a lovely walk and so relaxing. During high summer it's pretty rammed but lovely to enjoy the sun before high summer hits!

I was visiting Oxford and looking for some natural experience. That is when I found out port meadow from the google. It is walkable distance from the city centre. The place is quiet. If you are looking to have some quiet time and feel the nature while you are in Oxford; Port meadow is one of place you can visit. You can see swans swimming, horse grazing and people fishing while you are here

Port Meadow is one of Oxford's hidden gems. With vast riverside fields dotted with horses and cattle, it feels like stepping into the countryside just minutes from the city. It's perfect for walks, cycling, and watching stunning sunsets. The paths can get muddy after rain, and it's often busy on sunny weekends or swampy in winter, but it remains a must-visit for nature lovers. If you're lucky, a horse might even come over for a gentle nudge, and sometimes you'll see the herds of cows and horses subtly competing for territory.

places.address: Walton Well Rd, Oxford, OX2 6ED, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: The Pitt Rivers Museum, established in 1884 by Augustus Pitt Rivers, is a treasure trove of over 500,000 ethnographic objects, photographs, and manuscripts from various cultures and time periods. This museum in Oxford showcases an eclectic mix of artifacts from around the world, offering visitors a unique opportunity to explore humanity's history and cultural diversity.

sources.snippet: See displays of jewellery, musical instruments, textiles and other old-world antiquities at the Pitt Rivers Museum. Purchase Special Gifts and Souvenirs Treat your partner to something new from dozens of shops that spread through the heart of Oxford city centre. Unique and one-of-a-kind items are aplenty at the artisan stands and boutiques of the Covered Market.
sources.shortName: Romantic Things to Do in Oxford

sources.snippet: The Pitt Rivers Museum displays the world’s great collections of archaeological and anthropological collections of the University of Oxford, England. The museum can only be accessed through the Oxford University Museum of Natural History and The Pitt Rivers Museum is located to the east of the Oxford University Museum of Natural History.
sources.shortName: 20 Places to Visit in Oxford, Tourist Places & Top Attractions

sources.snippet: Lastly, the Pitt Rivers Museum stands out for those interested in anthropology and archaeology. Known for its fascinating and eclectic collection, the museum invites curiosity and wonder at every turn. From shrunken heads to intricate jewelry, the items on display are sure to spark discussions about cultures from around the globe.
sources.shortName: First Date Ideas in Oxford

sources.snippet: Take your pick, or head inside the eclectic (and free) Pitt Rivers Museum, which houses half a million artefacts. Take a peek at shrunken heads, ceremonial masks and a even totem pole and pick up a memento in the gift shop.
sources.shortName: Things to Do & Places to Visit in Oxford
8 Romantic Things To Do This Valentine’s Day In Oxford

places.name: Pitt Rivers Museum

reviews.text:
The Pitt Rivers Museum in Oxford is an extraordinary place, a true hidden gem filled with history, culture, and stories from around the world. Oxford is one of my home places, and I have visited this museum many times-both while working with families and children and in my free time. Each visit feels like stepping into a treasure chest of human heritage, where every object holds a secret waiting to be discovered.

The museum's atmosphere is truly unique, with dim lighting and endless shelves of artifacts creating a sense of mystery and wonder. You can spend hours exploring and still find something new each time. It's not just a collection of objects-it's a journey through time, teaching us so much about different civilizations, traditions, and ways of life.

Children, in particular, are always fascinated by the displays, making it a perfect place for families. Whether you love history, anthropology, or simply enjoy discovering the past through beautifully curated exhibits, this museum is an absolute must-visit. I highly recommend it to everyone-it's a magical experience that stays with you long after you leave.

A truly enthralling immersiive visitor experience in this one of a kind treasure trove. The Pitt Rivers and the  joined at the hip Natural History Museum in Oxford are a wonder for the architecture and interior design alone, let alone for the literally hundreds and  thousands of exhibits. Im sure one could spend a lifetime visiting and still not see everything. Better to have an hour or so and a light lunch in the first floor cafe to reflect, otherwise  'exhibit fatigue' could set in. For those visiting with mobility issues you can check the website and phone the museum ahead and book the disabled parking bay right next to the rear entrance. Lifts to all floors so everything is accessible. A cabinet of delights awaits you. You will not be disappointed.  Free entry but you'll want to spend money in the museums shops and cafe or donate to keep this wonderful place of learning and fun alive.

Genuinely one of the best museums I have ever been to. The collection is really packed, there is so much to see. Unlike many museums who tend to have a smaller selection but more information, this one really has so much to see.

Its natural history section is spacious and ideal for children and families, contained on one floor. The ethnographic section is contained within multiple levels.

As an avid arms and armour history buff, this is one of the most underrated museums. I don't hear many in the community talk about it, but this place has easily the best collection of ethnographic weaponry I have ever seen.

The best part is it's free. Its really worth the 5 pound recommended donation and more.

places.address: S Parks Rd, Oxford, OX1 3PP, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: Christ Church Meadow is a picturesque and expansive area in the heart of Oxford, bordered by the Cherwell and Thames rivers. It offers a charming rural escape within the city, perfect for leisurely walks or picnics with views of Christ Church College. Longhorn cattle graze on the tranquil pasture, adding to its idyllic atmosphere. Visitors can enter through various gates and enjoy romantic strolls around the sundial or admire sunsets over the meadows.

sources.snippet: Christ Church Meadow is another jewel in Oxford’s crown, offering picturesque views that blend the city’s rich history with the tranquility of nature. This meadow surrounds the iconic Christ Church College, providing a panoramic view of Oxford’s most famous spires. The paths meander alongside the River Thames and River Cherwell, passing under ancient trees and beside flower-filled meadows.
sources.shortName: First Date Ideas in Oxford

sources.snippet: Join the Thames Path at Christ Church Meadow and follow its meandering route along the riverbank to the market town of Abingdon. With colourful houseboats, historic locks and lush meadows to see on the way, there are boundless photo opportunities. Catch a local bus back to Oxford or enjoy a leisurely river cruise by punt and rented motorboat.
sources.shortName: Romantic Things to Do in Oxford

sources.snippet: Take a stroll through Christ Church Meadow and enjoy views along the river and back towards Christ Church College. Discover the UK’s oldest botanic garden that’s home to more than 5,000 different types of plants from all over the world.
sources.shortName: 8 Romantic Things To Do This Valentine’s Day In Oxford
A Romantic Guide to Oxford
Romantic Places To Visit In Oxford This Valentines | Oxford Travel Guide

places.name: Christ Church Meadow

reviews.text: A spectacular place! The church and the dining hall will leave you speechless. I highly recommend that you buy the £20 tour, which will tell you about the history of the place. It will take you roughly 2 hours to see the whole place.

Very nice park, open to public, on the historic Oxford Campus. Go for a morning run, if you are in the area, or a nice after dinner stroll. Pass through cricket fields, and wave to the boaters on the river.

Christ Church Meadow in Oxford is an absolute gem and a must-visit for anyone exploring the city! The stunning combination of natural beauty, rich history, and architectural grandeur makes it a truly magical experience. Strolling through the peaceful meadows, with picturesque views of the River Thames and the Cherwell, feels like stepping into a painting. The sight of Christ Church Cathedral rising in the background is simply breathtaking, and the tranquil atmosphere offers a perfect escape from the hustle and bustle of city life.

The highlight of our visit was undoubtedly the guided tour. The tour guides were nothing short of exceptional-friendly, knowledgeable, and clearly passionate about sharing the stories of this historic site. They expertly wove together the history of Christ Church College, its connections to some of the world's most influential figures, and the fascinating details of its architectural evolution. Their storytelling was captivating, filled with fun anecdotes about famous alumni like Lewis Carroll and explanations of how this iconic location inspired parts of “Alice in Wonderland” and scenes from the Harry Potter films.

What really stood out was how approachable and engaging the guides were. They took the time to answer all of our questions, whether about the college's historical significance, its ties to the British monarchy, or even the wildlife that inhabits the meadows. Their enthusiasm was infectious, making the tour not only educational but also incredibly enjoyable.

The experience feels like a blend of walking through history and stepping into a literary and cinematic wonderland. Whether you're a history enthusiast, a literature lover, a Harry Potter fan, or just someone who appreciates beautiful landscapes, Christ Church Meadow and its outstanding tours offer something special for everyone.

I cannot recommend this place enough. It's a perfect day out for families, solo travelers, or couples looking to soak in the magic of Oxford. The meadows, combined with the rich stories shared by the incredible tour guides, make it a truly unforgettable experience. If you're visiting Oxford, don't miss this treasure-it's the kind of place that stays with you long after you've left!

places.address: Oxford, OX1 4JF, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: Oxford Castle & Prison is a historic site that dates back to 1073 and offers a glimpse into the city's rich past. The castle, built by Norman invaders, has witnessed centuries of history and now welcomes visitors to explore its ancient halls and prison. Guided tours led by costumed guides provide access to intriguing spots such as the crypts, Debtors' Tower, Motte and Bailey Castle, and St George's Tower.

sources.snippet: For a touch of history and adventure, taking a guided tour of Oxford Castle & Prison can be an intriguing option. This historic site offers insights into Oxford’s past, with stories of intrigue, drama, and everyday life that span over a thousand years. The guided tour not only provides a glimpse into the castle and prison’s history but also offers a chance to explore the ancient buildings and climb the Saxon St. George’s Tower, offering breathtaking views of the city.
sources.shortName: First Date Ideas in Oxford

sources.snippet: Next, head out of Oxford to nearby Woodstock and the baroque Blenheim Palace. A UNESCO World Heritage Site and Winston Churchill’s birthplace is now also famous as the location for the Harry Potter tree, James Bond’s Spectre and Queen Charlotte. Stop for lunch or afternoon tea, in its lovely Orangery Restaurant and explore pristine parklands and award-winning formal gardens.
sources.shortName: Things to Do & Places to Visit in Oxford

sources.snippet: The partly ruined Oxford castle was built in 1071 for William, the conqueror. It was largely destroyed after the English Civil War since it was used as a prison for destructed Royalists. Most of the original wooden structures and bailey castles were replaced with stone in the late 12th or beginning of the 13th century.
sources.shortName: 20 Places to Visit in Oxford, Tourist Places & Top Attractions

places.name: Oxford Castle & Prison

reviews.text:
Historical & fun Castle & Prison
This is a really nice place to visit. I recommend arriving early as it can get quite packed in the afternoon. We enjoyed the whole area including seeing this mount & the prisons!
The castle was the highlight though for us, as it is very ancient and was a great first place to visit, before continuing onto other sites in Oxford.

Mostly prison as most of the castle was demolished. The tour guide (in full period costume) was excellent, and all the staff I encountered were similar. 101 stairs in a tight spiral  to the top of the tower might be a challenge for some. Its an interesting tour but an eclectic collection of themes.

We didn't plan to go into Oxford castle and Prison but so glad we did! Are Tour guide, Rory, was absolutely incredible at bringing the history of the building to life and made the experience what it is. It was very surreal to think that we were standing in the same rooms and walking the same corridors and staircases where all these events took place! Well worth a visit if you're in the area.

places.address: 44-46 Oxford Castle, Oxford, OX1 1AY, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: The Turf Tavern, a historic pub dating back to 1831, is located in Oxford. Situated down a charming alley called St Helens Passage, it boasts a lovely outdoor beer garden and ample indoor seating. This iconic establishment attracts university students, famous personalities, and regular tourists alike. Notably, former US President Bill Clinton was once a patron during his time as a Rhodes scholar at Oxford.

sources.snippet: Dating back to the 13th century, The Turf Tavern pub boasts rustic decor, low wooden beams, and inviting fireplaces, setting the stage for intimate conversations and cherished moments. The adventure begins with finding the pub itself, hidden away in Oxford’s narrow alleys, adding an element of discovery and excitement to your date. Start your evening  with a hearty meal from the menu, which features traditional British dishes made with fresh, locally sourced ingredients.
sources.shortName: 5 Romantic Things To Do in Oxford for Couples

sources.snippet: Down a cobbled alley located near the Bodleian library you'll find this absolute gem. The dimly lit vibe and low ceilings create quite the atmosphere. The tranquility and secrecy of this one make it all the more special and your date is bound to fall in love with it in seconds, if not you.
sources.shortName: The top 10 places to take a date in Oxford

sources.snippet: This is one of Oxford's oldest pubs and has a really traditional, cosy feel. If you want to mingle with the locals or just feel like you belong in Oxford, this is the place to be!
sources.shortName: 7 Things to do in Oxford on Your Romantic Weekend Break ...

places.name: Turf Tavern

reviews.text: As a huge fan of Inspector Morse TV show, the Turf Tavern was one of the must visit places during my short stay in Oxford, UK. The food was exquisite, and the beer too, of course. This is a pub full of history and celebrities have been coming around since the 19th century. I've loved it.

The Turf Tavern is one of Oxford's best hidden treasures. Tucked away down little alleyways, it's full of character and history, with a cozy atmosphere that makes it easy to spend hours here. The beer selection is excellent, and the fish and chips were amazing. The staff are always friendly and welcoming. Would definitely recommend to anytime thinking of visiting!

Accidentally stumbled upon this famous spot as I was just looking for a decent fish and chips. Was well worth it.

The atmosphere was fantastic, three outdoor seating spaces with character from its surroundings. You can order at the bar or use the QR code on the table, which I always prefer as you can customize your own order on your own time.

The fish and chips was great. Light batter, big piece, and both the fish and chips were salted well. Tartar sauce was also nice and pickly/acidic. Also appreciated the lemon being grilled!

Loved the atmosphere and food here, great place to grab a pint or meal.

places.address: 4 Bath Pl, Oxford, OX1 3SU, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: Christ Church Cathedral is a medieval Gothic and Romanesque cathedral that serves both Christ Church college and the local parish. It holds the unique position of being both a college chapel and the cathedral of the Diocese of Oxford. Despite its small size, it has a rich history dating back to before the Norman Conquest, with a shrine built in memory of St Frideswide, an Anglo-Saxon princess who founded a convent on the site.

sources.snippet: Christ Church Cathedral located in the heart of the city center stands out for having the only college chapel that is also a cathedral founded in the eighth century. Christ Church is one of Oxford University’s largest colleges. Several famous people have been educated at Christ Church including historians, scientists, lawyers, and authors.
sources.shortName: 20 Places to Visit in Oxford, Tourist Places & Top Attractions

sources.snippet: The best Oxford restaurants with views are in the city centre, where cocktail bars and European eateries offer sights of Oxford University and Christ Church Cathedral.
sources.shortName: 33 Romantic Restaurants near Oxford

places.name: Christ Church Cathedral

reviews.text:
This cathedral at Christ church is the college chapel as well as cathedral of Oxford. It's located within the college premises. It's definitely worth visiting if you are in Oxford. You can book a guided tour or self guided tour. We booked a self guided tour which comes with a device and headset. Device is interactive and you can get minute-long audio and video explanations of the different parts. Harry Potter fans will easily recognize some of the places.
To me the main highlight of the cathedral was it's beautiful stained glass window, architecture and cloisters.

Unimaginable beauty. If you are considering a trip to Oxford from London or anywhere for that matter you need to stop here. There is so much rich history and architectural beauty on display it is hard to believe it was created 100s of years ago. Furthermore, if you are a Harry Potter fan, this feels like you are walking down the halls of Hogwarts. Highly recommend!

Christ Church Cathedral, located in Oxford, is a stunning architectural masterpiece and one of the most famous cathedrals in England. As the mother church of the Diocese of Oxford, it boasts a rich history dating back to the 12th century. The cathedral features a blend of Gothic and Romanesque architectural styles, with its impressive stained glass windows, intricate stone carvings, and a majestic vaulted ceiling.

Inside, visitors can admire the beautiful choir and the famous Christ Church organ, as well as the remarkable memorials and artworks that reflect its historical significance. The cathedral is also home to the Christ Church College, adding to its vibrant academic atmosphere.

Surrounded by picturesque gardens and the serene ambiance of Oxford, Christ Church Cathedral is a must-visit for those interested in history, architecture, and the spiritual heritage of the area. Its combination of beauty and historical importance makes it a highlight of any visit to Oxford.

Please be aware that the staff inside Christ Church may not come across as very friendly and might seem somewhat rude.

places.address: St Aldate's, Oxford, OX1 1DP, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: The New Theatre Oxford, with its ornate seating for 1800 people, is a versatile venue hosting a wide range of performances including drama, opera, gigs, comedy and dance. It also offers children's events during school holidays and youth drama activities. The theater has been known to host popular shows throughout the year including a great Panto. Additionally, it offers same day return tickets for families along with parking options.

sources.snippet: For those who love live music, stand-up comedy, or theatre, the centuries-old New Theatre is a great spot for a romantic evening date. Think West End shows like Dirty Dancing and Six, and comedy from the likes of Russell Howard and Jimmy Carr, and you’re on the right lines. With a myriad of things on at any one time, you’re sure to find something to suit the vibe of your date.
sources.shortName: Date Ideas Oxford: 15 Romantic Things to Do in Oxford [2024]

sources.snippet: Located on George Street the New Theatre Oxford has a host of showings from comedians to film festivals, you’re bound to something you’ll enjoy. Oxford Playhouse also has a jam-packed programme of theatrical performances throughout the year. Take a look at their website to find a show you’ll both enjoy.
sources.shortName: 8 Romantic Things To Do This Valentine’s Day In Oxford

places.name: New Theatre Oxford

reviews.text: A huge theatre with plenty of show options. We watched Chicago which was a great show. The seats sisnt have very much leg room, however the seats were comfy. The bar staff were polite, and the drinks reasonably priced.

I have visited quite a few theatres in England and this is one of the best. Large auditorium and good service at the bars. Great legroom which i was surprised about. Look forward to coming back, hopefully to see Derren Brown again. Only downside was the fact that it was roasting inside, but I understand this is how most theatres are and it's hard to get around it. If you're visiting in the summer, consider the possibility that it will be hot inside.
First time here. Lovely theatre, plenty of leg room and plenty of bar areas. Staff are nice too. Recommended.

places.address: 24-26 George St, Oxford, OX1 2AG, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: The Trout Inn is an upscale country gastropub located on the banks of the River Thames, offering picturesque views and a beer garden where families of peacocks roam. This historic establishment has inspired literary greats like Lewis Carroll and Inspector Morse's creator, Colin Dexter. The inn retains its historical charm with exposed beams and a cozy atmosphere, while also offering modern comforts. Situated in the beautiful riverside scenery of Oxfordshire, it provides a menu that satisfies visitors' appetites.

sources.snippet: Oxford has two theatres that have a steady programme of events. So this Valentine’s Day why not take your other half to a play at the theatre?. Located on George Street the New Theatre Oxford has a host of showings from comedians to film festivals, you’re bound to something you’ll enjoy.
sources.shortName: 8 Romantic Things To Do This Valentine’s Day In Oxford

places.name: The Trout Inn

reviews.text:
Great atmosphere in a lovely location. It was a sunny day so we sat outside.
They have plenty of informal and formal seating areas which was great as we only wanted to get a few drinks and nibbles. Had shaded areas too.
Drinks came quickly but the nibbles did take a while. Wasn't an issue as we were chatting away. Both the drink and food was amazing and reasonably priced. Service was friendly and pleasant.
Good sized free parking but I can imagine this to be quite full when busy.

Had a lovely experience at the trout. The staff was incredibly kind, helpful and accommodating. One of our group had difficulty coping with the music and they kindly offered to lower it. The service was very good and the food came without having to wait too long. As well as our table, we booked it half an our later, but we arrived earlier. The staff managed to find a table for us even though we were early!

On Sunday we recommend the Sunday roasts as they were delicious! As well as the classic fish and chips and for a lighter meal the house salad with fish will be perfect.

The mini dessert was a surprising, but good combination! A small desert and a cup of coffee, perfect!

Iv been coming to this lovely place over many years and its great on a summers day sat by the water.
The place itself is beautiful but the outside could do with some TLC as looking forgotten and some tables are broken and need replacing.
But please don't let this put you off.  Great place and friendly staff.
The food we ate today was good and full love flavour. I booked a table over the phone as booking online was not working.
Monday 12.30 booking Waited about 15-20 minutes from ordering food to it arriving.
Free parking if you enter your Reg on arrival.

places.address: 195 Godstow Rd, Wolvercote, Oxford OX2 8PN, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: Oxford Botanic Garden is Britain's oldest botanic garden, featuring a diverse collection of plants from around the world. Situated near the River Cherwell, this peaceful garden was established in 1621 for the study of medicinal plants. Visitors can explore both indoor and outdoor sections to admire a wide variety of plant species. The garden is located in an area that offers numerous sightseeing attractions, fun activities, local cultural experiences, dining options, and budget-friendly accommodations.

sources.snippet: At the top of the list is the University of Oxford Botanic Garden. This spot isn’t just a garden; it’s a living library of plants from all around the world. The diverse collection of flora provides a stunning setting for a leisurely walk, allowing you and your date to wander through beautifully landscaped areas, each with its own theme and story.
sources.shortName: First Date Ideas in Oxford

sources.snippet: There are few things more romantic than going for a stroll around a garden, and Oxford Botanic Garden and Arboretum is the place to do it in the city!. Founded in 1621, it’s the UK’s oldest botanic garden which is reason enough to visit, right?. No matter the season, the garden is always a delight and a calm oasis away from the city centre.
sources.shortName: Date Ideas Oxford: 15 Romantic Things to Do in Oxford [2024]

sources.snippet: The Oxford Botanic Garden was founded in 1621 and it is the oldest surviving Botanic Garden in Britain. The Botanic Garden was formerly known as Physick or Physic Garden and had a collection of medical plants. Now, the southwest corner of the Oxford Botanic Garden is home to a collection of modern medical plants.
sources.shortName: 20 Places to Visit in Oxford, Tourist Places & Top Attractions

sources.snippet: The Oxford Botanic Garden reveals different charms through the seasons. Spring brings clouds of cherry blossoms, summer offers rose garden romance, autumn paints everything in gold and crimson, while winter transforms the Victorian glasshouses into cosy havens.
sources.shortName: A Romantic Guide to Oxford

places.name: Oxford Botanic Garden

reviews.text: Oxford Botanical Garden was stunning.  We visited end of May and blooms everywhere. My favorite are the roses. But everything is gorgeous.  Also the staff there was so helpful. I left my wallet at the gift shop and they found it and kept it for me. I am very thankful. This is must see, We make an effort to visit tjus garden when in Oxford. And end of May was the perfect time for blooms.

Wonderful collection of plants I loved the orchard ate sone grapes, apples and pears all very delicious.  Wish the green houses were bigger but there are many to view. Lovely day trip this garden was our high light of our trip. Definitely recommend entry was £10

The UK's oldest botanic garden, situated in the city of Oxford, is home to a wide variety of plants from around the world. Colourful floral borders in the walled garden, well kept herb gardens, and greenhouses of cacti and carnivorous plants are amongst the highlights, all well curated with informative display boards.
The gardens are easy to navigate, with well kept paths and full wheelchair accessibility. It's easily possible to spend 1.5 to 2 hours exploring all the garden's different areas. Facilities are good, with a small gift shop and toilets onsite.
At the time of my visit in June 2025, the entry fee was £9, which seemed reasonable considering the variety of plants to see and the standard of presentation. Guided tours are available from 14:30 on Thursdays and Sundays between April and September.

places.address: Rose Ln, Oxford, OX1 4AZ, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: The Radcliffe Camera is a stunning 18th-century academic library and reading room located in the heart of Oxford. Designed by the renowned architect James Gibbs, this Palladian-style building stands as a centerpiece in Radcliffe Square, surrounded by other significant landmarks such as the Bodlein Library and St Mary's church. The majestic circular structure, funded by Dr. John Radcliffe's estate, features a magnificent dome and towering pillars that have made it an iconic symbol of the city.

sources.snippet: The Bodleian Library and Radcliffe Camera are just some of the places visible. Picnic in Port Meadow Sprawling Port Meadow skirts the River Thames and feels more like a Cotswolds countryside setting than the edge of the city centre. Fill your picnic hamper with goodies, throw down a blanket and bask amid birdsong, wildflowers and wild ponies.
sources.shortName: Romantic Things to Do in Oxford

sources.snippet: The Radcliffe Camera is one of the iconic sights in Oxford, England. It was built between 1737 and 1749 with £40,000 bequeathed by the royal physician, Dr. John Radcliffe, and designed by several leading architects, including Nicholas Hawksmoor and James Gibbs. It is one of the unique landmarks in the city of distinctive landmarks.
sources.shortName: 20 Places to Visit in Oxford, Tourist Places & Top Attractions

places.name: Radcliffe Camera

reviews.text: The Rad Cam is a remarkable piece of architecture- beautiful both inside and out. A wonderful experience to sit there and read.

The Radcliffe Camera is one of the most iconic and beautiful buildings in Oxford. Its grand circular design and historic architecture make it a must-see, even if you're just walking through the city. It looks stunning from every angle-especially when the sun hits the stone.

You can't go inside unless you're part of the university or on a guided tour, but honestly, the real charm is just being there and taking in the view from Radcliffe Square. Surrounded by other impressive buildings like the Bodleian Library and All Souls College, the whole area has a timeless, academic feel.

Perfect for photos, a quiet stroll, or just to admire one of Oxford's most photographed landmarks. Definitely worth stopping by if you're visiting the city.

The most iconic place in Oxford. Must visit.
If you're a traveller, I have a little tip for you. Taking a picture with this Baroque-style circular library requires some careful thought, as most of the photos you see online are probably taken using drones (see below, credits to the amazing Reagan Yip). It is quite difficult to fit yourself into the photo without sacrificing the view. The best photo spot, I learnt, is a balcony inside Exeter College, which is not open to the public. You can consider a low-angle shot - see the matriculation photo below for inspiration - as it captures the impressive Rad Cam whilst adding a tinge of creativity. Certainly a refreshing take on an extremely popular spot.

If you're a student, my honest take is: go somewhere else to study. The interior is gorgeous no doubt, and at some point you should visit this library at least once, but your Bod Card can get you to much nicer study spaces. To quote Robert Frost:

“Two roads diverged in a wood, and I-
I took the one less traveled by,
And that has made all the difference.”

places.address: Radcliffe Sq, Oxford, OX1 3BG, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: Carfax Tower, a 23-meter-high bell tower, is a historic landmark in Oxford, England. It was originally part of St. Martin's Church dating back to the 12th century and offers panoramic views of the city from its top. Despite the church being demolished to make way for traffic, the tower remains remarkably well-preserved. Visitors can climb 99 steps to reach the peak and enjoy breathtaking vistas of Oxford's city center.

sources.snippet: In the centre of Oxford, only a 4-minute walk from our boutique hotel, Carfax tower; the remains of the 14th Century Church of St. Martin dominates the skyline. Climb the 99 steps to the top of the tower and take in Oxford all at once at its very best. Watch the leaves from a unique perspective float and fall from the tops of the trees among the sea of burnt sienna, auburn and rouge.
sources.shortName: Romantic Autumn Activities in Oxfordshire for Couples

sources.snippet: Oxford’s answer to the Eiffel Tower, it’s basically the UK’s city of love. It’s cheap, you get a nice view of your partner’s bottom as you embark the tiny, cramped staircase and you can take some sickly-sweet photos of kissing over the skyline and creaming, sorry, dreaming spires. Laurie says: “It’s no Chicken Cottage, but there is a certain allure to the altitude.
sources.shortName: Best Places To Go On a Date In Oxford

sources.snippet: Carfax Tower, located in the heart of Oxford, is a historic landmark offering panoramic views of the city. This 74-foot tower, once part of a 13th-century church, is a must-visit for its rich history and stunning vistas of Oxford's iconic spires. A perfect spot for photography and exploration!
sources.shortName: 20 Places to Visit in Oxford, Tourist Places & Top Attractions

sources.snippet: The two main towers that the city has is St Mary’s Tower and the Carfax Tower. From the top of these buildings you get a wonderful view of the famous spires across the city.
sources.shortName: Romantic Places To Visit In Oxford This Valentines | Oxford Travel Guide

places.name: Carfax Tower

reviews.text: Carfax Tower, a prominent landmark in Oxford, is the sole remaining portion of the 12th-century St. Martin's Church, which served as the city's official church for centuries. In 1896, the church was largely demolished to alleviate traffic congestion at the busy crossroads of Carfax, leaving the tower as a historical vestige. You can climb the 99 steps to the top for panoramic views of Oxford, and only £4.

Apparently all students at Oxford must be accommodated within a 6 mile radius of this tower which was the centre of the old town of Oxford. Views are fantastic and its not busy like the tower at St. Mary's University Church. Good way to spend 15 minutes getting to know the layout of Oxford as well as learning a little bit about what Oxford was like in the 18th century.

Going up the Carfax Tower is so worth doing.  I got 360 view of the entire town. It's a tiny yet amazingly constructed tower that's just right at the heart of Oxford.  I love the view up the tower.  There was no queue on Sunday lunch time that let me enjoy the view at my own pace. The tower has a tiny steep stairs around 99 steps so not for very small children or people with mobility problems.

places.address: Queen St, Oxford, OX1 1ET, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: Pierre Victoire is a charming French bistro located in the heart of Oxford, offering a delightful dining experience with its relaxed, candlelit ambiance and wooden furniture adorned with fresh flowers. The restaurant's fixed-price menu options provide an affordable way to savor traditional French cuisine prepared by skilled chefs. The staff, dressed in traditional berets and striped shirts, exude a warm and welcoming atmosphere that adds to the overall charm of the place.

sources.snippet: Every couple I know at Oxford has celebrated some birthday or anniversary at Pierre Victoire, and it will become obvious why it’s everyone’s go-to hidden gem. Nestled in a cosy enclave on Little Clarendon Street, the French cult favourite has everything you might expect from a romantic date in the movies—candles, dimmed lighting, piano music, and fondue for dessert. And at under £30 for a two-course meal, it isn’t too unhealthy for the budget either.
sources.shortName: Date Spots

sources.snippet: On Little Clarendon Street,  Pierre Victoire brings the romance of Paris to Oxford. This French bistro, with its quaint and charming interior, adorned with vintage posters and rustic wooden tables, offers a cozy and romantic setting. The menu at Pierre Victoire is a celebration of classic French cuisine, offering everything from sumptuous escargots to rich boeuf bourguignon.
sources.shortName: 5 dining spots for a date in Oxford

places.name: Pierre Victoire

reviews.text: Finally I was able to book a table and enjoyed a wonderful brunch with my bestie. And I just realized that online booking access is open on their instagram page!! Truly, highly recommend it to y'all. Their chicken liver is very tasty, like melting in the mouth. Love it!

Nice restaurant. Overall the food is are good and with good price.

Most people ordered the steak. The steak is nice except the fries. The fries are not fresh.

Sitting at second floor is a good idea as the window is opened and with better ventilation. Also, quiet. You can enjoy your meal there.

We arrived right on time at 12:00 noon, and the restaurant was completely full within 45 minutes.

We ordered one two-course and one three-course lunch set. For the starters, we had calamari and French onion soup. The calamari was tender, and the soup was well-seasoned and perfectly balanced with the crispy bread.

For the main courses, we had slow-braised duck leg and fresh mussels. As the menu stated, the mussels were incredibly fresh and creamy. They really whetted our appetites, and we couldn't stop eating! The duck leg was tender and flavorful. The most amazing part was the rösti underneath, which absorbed the orange sauce and made the dish even more incredible. The chocolate mousse was the perfect ending to our lunch.

The staff are polite and efficient. An excellent experience for our Oxford trip! Thank you!

places.address: 9 Little Clarendon St, Oxford, OX1 2HP, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: Cherwell Boathouse Restaurant offers an upscale European dining experience in an Edwardian boathouse located by the river. The restaurant has been operating for over a century and offers punt hire from mid-March to mid-October. The menu features hearty dishes such as braised shoulder of lamb, blade of Oxfordshire beef, and roast chicken.

sources.snippet: Next on the list is The Cherwell Boathouse, an idyllic riverside restaurant known for its classic British cuisine. What sets this place apart is not just its food but also the opportunity to rent a punt for a romantic outing on the river before or after your meal. The combination of dining by the water’s edge and enjoying a leisurely punt ride offers a uniquely Oxford experience, blending fine dining with the beauty of the city’s waterways.
sources.shortName: First Date Ideas in Oxford

sources.snippet: If you’re a fan of a creative range of dishes and love best-kept secret locations, Cherwell Boathouse is your destination. At an 11-minute drive from our site, this understated yet upscale venue not only has a delectable choice of meals, the waterfront also has punts for hire!. Feel like the star of your own Hollywood movie for a day at Cherwell Boathouse.
sources.siteName: Vanbrugh House Hotel | Just another WordPress site
sources.shortName: 5 Most Romantic Places to Eat in Oxford

sources.snippet: If you like your meals with a view, book a riverfront table at Cherwell Boathouse, a family-owned restaurant housed in an authentic Victorian boathouse. Seasonal menus include the likes of crab cannelloni, beer-brined poussin and a 10-layered vegetable lasagne. chef’s kiss Work off your leisurely lunch afterwards by taking a punt on the river.
sources.shortName: Things to Do & Places to Visit in Oxford

places.name: Cherwell Boathouse Restaurant

reviews.text:
An incredible setting to host an event!
I had the pleasure of photographing a wedding at Cherwell Boathouse this season and it was beautiful. A waterside setting, with the bride and groom punting in for their arrival, a fabulous wedding breakfast in the marquee followed by an epic party in the lower boathouse.
Highly recommend this venue for any private or corporate events.

We visited for our anniversary and were welcomed into a lovely atmosphere with friendly, attentive service. We enjoyed a three-course meal each - both the starter and main courses were excellent. However, we were a little disappointed with the dessert cheese sharing board. Having to ask for butter was unexpected, and the portion size felt small for the price. That said, it was still a very pleasant experience overall, and the corkage fee was fair.

Probably the worst experience I had in a restaurant.

Made a reservation for a special dinner for our wedding anniversary and asked a special request. They had my name on the reservation but did not reserve a table so when we arrived we got whatever table was left.

The chairs and tables are small and wonky making it really difficult to eat as everything is almost falling out. Barely any space between tables and chairs back to back making your meal a ‘family' meal as we are so closed to other people you could reach their food with your fork.

The food wasn't anything special. Worse than that my ‘pink' steak was completely raw. Fries overcooked and very dark brown.

Took 20 minutes to get our order and had to request twice to the waiters floating around. The bill equally the same time to wait.

Do not recommend. Expensive and low quality products and terrible customer service.

places.address: Bardwell Rd, Oxford, OX2 6ST, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: Brasserie Blanc is an upscale French restaurant chain with a menu curated by the renowned chef Raymond Blanc. The Brasserie Blanc in Oxford's Jericho area offers a vibrant and inviting atmosphere just a short walk from the city center. The restaurant presents classic French dishes with a modern twist, showcasing the best of French cuisine.

sources.snippet: Brasserie Blanc in Jericho is a delightful French restaurant that exudes romance and elegance. As Raymond Blanc’s first branch, it holds a special place in the heart of Oxford. The beautifully decorated interior, excellent service and classic high-quality food make it a firm favourite for a romantic evening.
sources.shortName: A Guide to the Best Restaurants for Date Night

sources.snippet: French is universally considered the language of love, so for this special day, Brasserie Blanc is the place to be!. At a short 15-minute walk from our hotel, this upscale chain surely won’t disappoint. From à la carte to a set menu, there’s something for everyone.
sources.siteName: Vanbrugh House Hotel | Just another WordPress site
sources.shortName: 5 Most Romantic Places to Eat in Oxford

places.name: Brasserie Blanc Oxford

reviews.text:
Heard so much about this Oxford institution and was not disappointed. The Mediterranean Soup was dense, full of fishy goodness in a good way. I tried the Cheese Soufflé of my dinner partner and I got to admit, I might have preferred that to my soup. Soups are everywhere but that soufflé is hard to find.

For my mains I had the Pan Fried Sea Bream. Crispy on the outside but juicy in the inside. The bouillabaisse sauce and sauteed squid complimented the fish really well.

Enjoyed this.

We had the duck legs and the sea bream, and both dishes were beautifully prepared-flavourful, well-seasoned, and cooked to perfection. The presentation was elegant without being overdone. The service was also excellent-friendly, attentive, and professional throughout the meal. A thoroughly enjoyable dining experience. Highly recommended.

Brasserie Blanc in Oxford offers a delightful blend of British and French classics in a warm, inviting setting just off Jericho. The food is consistently excellent-beautifully presented, flavourful, and made with quality ingredients-while the service is charming and attentive without being overbearing. Relaxed family lunch, it's a reliably lovely spot.

places.address: 71-72 Walton St, Oxford, OX2 6AG, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: The Bear Inn in Oxford is a traditional pub with a rich history dating back to 1242, making it the oldest surviving pub in the city. Situated in what was once the medieval red-light district of Magpie Lane, this low-ceilinged establishment boasts creaky floorboards and a fascinating collection of cut-off ties from various sports teams, colleges, and university clubs. The pub has been frequented by notable figures such as Shelley, Auden, and Graham Greene.

sources.snippet: Round off a long day of exploring Oxford with a trip to The Bear Inn, which has been serving locals since 1242. Order a pint of ale and kick back in the heated garden or grab a table indoors in the colder months. The interiors of this old-school boozer are particularly distinctive, thanks to its collection of over 4,500 snippets of ties displayed on the walls and ceiling.
sources.shortName: Things to Do & Places to Visit in Oxford

sources.snippet: The bear is tucked away down a side street just off High Street and is perfect if you want your date to be a little discreet and get an intimate chat going. There are also some cute benches outside with the addition of some classy heaters, so need to worry about getting cold and having to lend your date a jumper which you'll probably never see again.
sources.shortName: The top 10 places to take a date in Oxford

places.name: The Bear Inn, Oxford

reviews.text: We loved the historical feel of the place.  It was tiny inside but everything was so original.  Visited the ladies and it was an experience.  The food was excellent!  The fish and chips was cooked perfect and non-greasy at all.

I relished the opportunity to visit Oxford's oldest remaining pub, appreciating the gorgeous interior still standing! The fireplace is nice and the collection of ties is fascinating, even found Cambridge on there. I had a pint of their strawberry cider, coming in at around £5 which is fine for Oxford prices!

The Bear Inn is exactly what you picture when you think of an old English pub-tiny inside, full of character, and super cozy. Seating indoors is limited, so you might have to squeeze in, but that's part of the charm. The menu is kind of all over the place, with everything from nachos to pimientos de padrón to salads. Not your usual pub fare, but it keeps things interesting. The food was decent overall, nothing amazing, but tasty enough. It's a bit pricey for what it is, but you're mostly paying for the cool, historic vibe. Great spot to check out if you're in Oxford.

places.address: 6 Alfred St, Oxford, OX1 4EH, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: Sandy's Piano Bar, located on King Edward Street in Oxford, is a classy underground speakeasy that offers original cocktails, wines by the glass, and live entertainment. The bar exudes an intimate and relaxed atmosphere with knowledgeable staff ensuring drinks keep flowing until late every night. Live music is a staple at Sandy's, featuring resident pianists and visiting jazz bands that perform nightly.

sources.snippet: Sandy’s Piano Bar is one of Oxford’s very best live music venues and cocktail bars, open until late every night. Live music is in the bar’s bloodstream, and they’re amazing at it, so check out their events calendar and see what takes your fancy for your next date in Oxford. Whether it’s an open mic night or a professional performance, you’re sure to find something to liven up your date!
sources.shortName: Date Ideas Oxford: 15 Romantic Things to Do in Oxford [2024]

sources.snippet: Oxford’s best live music venue, Sandy’s Piano Bar is an unbeatable date idea in Oxford. The underground speakeasy is dimly lit, setting the vibe for a romantic date, it also serves the best cocktails and has an impressive wine list. The bar is also well known for having the best service in Oxford, filled with staff who love helping you pick cocktails to suit your taste.
sources.shortName: 11 Wonderful Date Ideas In Oxford

sources.snippet: If you want to impress your date with a selection of cocktails and wines, Sandy’s is the place for you. It is famous for having the best bartenders in Oxford who are hugely knowledgeable of the menu, so it is a perfect chance to try something new. The bar is famous for its live music in the evenings, which creates the perfect ambience for a romantic evening.
sources.shortName: 10 date ideas in Oxford

sources.snippet: If your date likes banging (on some piano keys obviously) and a bit of live music, then Sandy's piano bar is perfect. It's super groovy and if your conversation comes to an awkward standstill, you can pretend you're in the zone and nod your head to the music or something. Plus, there are acts on every night and at weekends until 3am.
sources.shortName: The top 10 places to take a date in Oxford

places.name: Sandy's Piano Bar

reviews.text:
Amazing place totally visited by chance but i'm so glad we did. Really nice atmosphere and we also had some delicious cocktails too. I loved the way the music was set up and the sound quality was perfect. The artist playing on the night of 17/09/24 was smashing it and we really enjoyed ourselves!

P.S if you see this review feel free to use the pic

Music is really good but the venue is Tiny (hence the 3 stars) They need bigger premises or redesign the current layout! If you book a table good luck trying to get to the bar! No drinks table service offered ! So fight your way through the crowd to get to the bar, the cocktails are good. The venue seems to want to crowd in as many people as possible so if you do make it to the bar be prepared to end up wearing most of your drink going back to the table area after fighting through the crowd. We would have spent much more at the bar if this was offered!
Every time I've been here the bouncer on the door seems reluctant to want to let you in! Or it's the staff  inside take ages responding to him on his radio.
Other people were also stood outside trying to explain they also had a booking and weren't being let in.

Loved it, came for a friend's birthday and everyone in our group had a great time. Started upstairs before making our way down to dance, sing and laugh all night. Highlight was definitely my friend being sung to by the whole bar! Fantastic atmosphere, great music and decent prices for drinks. Highly recommend, will return!

places.address: 4 King Edward St, Oxford, OX1 4HS, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: The Folly Restaurant is a charming cafe located in the heart of Oxford, offering modern British cuisine with a unique riverside terrace. Situated near the Westgate centre, it provides a one-of-a-kind dining experience by the beautiful River Thames. The restaurant prides itself on using the freshest seasonal ingredients to create delicious dishes served in an elegant manner. Its floating terrace, positioned under the iconic Folly Bridge, offers stunning views and adds to its appeal.

sources.snippet: The Folly Restaurant, located in Oxford on the banks of the Thames, offers a unique and charming dining experience. With a menu featuring modern European cuisine, diners can enjoy a variety of delicious dishes while taking in the beautiful waterfront terrace view. The restaurant’s elegant setting, with candles and lamps creating a cosy atmosphere, is perfect for a special meal out.
sources.shortName: A Guide to the Best Restaurants for Date Night

sources.snippet: If you’re looking for a classic European twist on this special day, look no further than The Folly. This astonishing waterside restaurant radiates charm – identical to the exquisite menu which is influenced by mainland European dishes. Situated only a 12-minute walk away from our boutique hotel, you can enjoy a pleasant walk back along the waterfront.
sources.siteName: Vanbrugh House Hotel | Just another WordPress site
sources.shortName: 5 Most Romantic Places to Eat in Oxford
8 Romantic Things To Do This Valentine’s Day In Oxford

places.name: The Folly Restaurant

reviews.text:
We recently had the pleasure of celebrating part of our intimate wedding day at The Folly Oxford, and we couldn't have asked for a better experience. Our guests arrived a little earlier than we did whilst we had a wonder round the city, but from the moment we arrived, the staff made us feel welcomed, providing a great atmosphere. The service made everything feel effortless, allowing us and our guests to relax and truly enjoy our special day. We had some bar snacks and bread tapas alongside our drinks which was fantastic to keep everyone going on a busy day.

One of the highlights was undoubtedly the cocktail river cruise. The cruise staff were very friendly and knowledgeable, adding to the stunning views of Oxford. Our family haven't stopped complimenting the cruise and it was loved by everyone, the blankets were a great touch as well!!

It was the perfect way to celebrate with our family and create unforgettable memories together - thank you!

took a cruise and dine experience. have to say it was great. the boat ride was great, the captain offered knowledge and insight into the area.
the tour covered boat houses and iffley lock.
the restaurant has a layout with inside and outside seating. the food was great quality and arrived hot and fresh.

Oh dear!
Great location with riverside views. First experience was the loo - crap, pardon the pun but hygiene and cleanliness were not up to scratch. Also general state of dining room, tables, etc. This begs the question as to the state of the kitchen!
Staff looked like they had just walked in from the street. Some made the effort but not what you expect at a restaurant that was selling it self at this level. Food was mediocre. I had lamb that really didn't have a lot of flavour and croquets that were... out of a packet? Wine again was very mediocre.
Michelin starred prices without the Michelin starred experience. Disappointing, will not be returning, not recommended by me.

places.address: 1 Folly Brg, Oxford, OX1 4JU, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: If you're on the hunt for a mini-golf experience that breaks the mold, look no further than Junkyard Golf Club in Oxford. This vibrant venue features three uniquely themed crazy golf courses, each offering its own quirky challenges and surprises. Perfect for families or groups of friends, this indoor haven is an explosion of color with neon lights and lively music that sets the stage for a memorable outing.

sources.snippet: A night at Junkyard Golf is definitely one of the most entertaining activities on offer in the city. With three nine-hole crazy golf courses to choose from and a vibrant atmosphere, this is a date night that promises plenty of fun. The golf course is home to a bar offering a wide selection of alcoholic drinks, and the venue is over-18’s only.
sources.shortName: 10 date ideas in Oxford

sources.snippet: Instead of having a conventional face-to-face conversation over dinner, it allows you to keep the chat going as there’s always something to talk about. Plus, it’s  really fun!. The best place to play crazy golf in Oxford is Junkyard Golf Club, which is famous the nation over for its crazy cocktails and even crazier courses.
sources.shortName: Date Ideas Oxford: 15 Romantic Things to Do in Oxford [2024]

sources.snippet: With three courses to choose from, you’re bound to have endless fun. Although they aren’t the only mini-golf course around. Whether you prefer an outdoor course boasting scenic views or an indoor setup with quirky decor, mini-golf promises a delights blend of recreation and intimacy.
sources.shortName: 8 Romantic Things To Do This Valentine’s Day In Oxford

sources.snippet: If you’re stuck on what to do on your date night in Oxford, putt over to Junkyard Golf. With three nine-hole crazy golf courses to choose from, this is the place for a lively date night. Challenge your significant other to a game or two and the loser can buy the next round.
sources.shortName: 11 Wonderful Date Ideas In Oxford

places.name: Junkyard Golf Club | Crazy Golf Oxford

reviews.text: This was an exciting venue for golfing, where we went on the Garry course! Derelict cars are fun to play golf over their fronts and rears, road signs create the atmosphere too. Holes include slides and blocks to navigate around, last room has fabulous glow in the dark vibes with different colour chutes to go down!

Had an amazing experience at Junkyard yesterday! The staff were super friendly and accommodating, especially Craig, big shout out to him! He really made the difference on our special day, can't wait to come back again soon. Thanks!

Great night out! And great service especially from ‘Grace' behind the bar very accommodating and showing us all of the facilities including the cloakroom and where to start our golf! Great cocktails too!

places.address: Castle St, Oxford, OX1 1NU, United Kingdom
